Is anyone here familiar with the concept of "Peak Oil"? I'm interested in hearing others' opinions and ideas around the topic...
 
 A quick, simplistic summary of the idea is that even though there is plenty of oil left to be extracted from the earth, at some point, actual production of that oil will begin to decline. (Because oil is non-renewable, this is inevitable.) At the same time, based on current usage and growth, demand for cheap energy and fuels will continue to increase. The ever-widening gap has the potential to seriously impact human life on earth.
 
 For a more detailed explanation, do a google search on "Peak Oil," or check out this website for one particular person's perspective: www.lifeaftertheoilcrash.net
 
 Here are a few items that may be surprising to some people:
 o Most estimates place the total amount of oil ever on earth at around 2 trillion barrels. We have used about 1 trillion barrels to date.
 
 o Some 'experts' believe we may have already reached 'peak oil.' The most extreme estimates I've seen place it 10-25 years out... but still within a generation or so. Regardless of the timeframe, it is inevitable assuming our current usage of oil.
 
 o According to many 'experts,' there is no viable replacement for oil (either individually or in combination with other energy sources) that is anywhere near ready for deployment on a large-scale.
 
 o There is no alternative renewable fuel source that comes close to matching the EROEI (energy returned on energy invested) of oil.
 
 o Some proposed 'energy sources' actually have a negative EROEI -- such as hydrogen, and by some estimates, ethanol.
 
 o In order to harness renewable sources of energy (wind, sun, water, etc.), it takes significant energy and materials to do so. 
 
 o Consider that the vast majority of the food produced today is possible through the use of fossil-fueled equipment to plant, harvest, and distribute. Consider that biological law dictates that a biological population will only be as large as the food supply of that population allows it to be. IF alternative energy sources are not found to power the food production and distribution, it will not be feasible to continue to produce the amount of food that is being produced today.
 
 That's all for now...
 
 Peace,
 The Bootfitter

Well, this subject unnerved me and I'm not sure why. I certainly don't subscribe to apocalyptic scenarios, and it seems as though even if oil were to dry up, alternative sources can be developed. Yes?

 Regardless of the accuracy of some of the 'alarmist' websites and books that address the topic, the reality is that 'peak oil' will happen. It is inevitable assuming we continue to use non-renewable resources. (Which seems to be a pretty safe assumption for right now.) Even if we find a LOT more oil, coal, and natural gas, the extraction of these resources will peak at some point. We may be able to extend it a few years... perhaps even a few generations... but it will happen. Especially when you consider that the population continues to grow... and the growing population demands more resources.
 
 I think the key question is whether we, collectively as the human race, will be able to develop alternative sources that are as conducive to economic growth (read: inexpensive) as oil has been up to this point. If peak oil happens anytime in the next generation or two as most experts are predicting, it appears unlikely that we will have alternative energy sources as widely available and as inexpensive as oil is now -- particularly for transportation.
 
 But even if we do that... The fact remains that our current system of food production and economics is not sustainable. The amount of available food for any biological population dictates the extent to which that population may grow. That is a simple biological law to which humans are not immune. 
 
 As we continue to increase food production, the world population continues to grow. As the population continues to grow, food production is increased in order to 'keep up.' It's a vicious cycle. Ending it would likely be considered 'cruel,' since it would necessarily mean that some humans already in existence would not get enough food intentionally. Not ending the cycle means that 200+ species per day* will continue to become extinct in the world ecological system. (*This is a figure that is often quoted by Daniel Quinn -- the individual who wrote Ishmael and several other books. I have not taken the time to independently verify his figures. See www.ishmael.org if you are not familiar with Quinn's work.) Converting the world's finite amount of biomass to human biomass is not 'healthy' for the world ecology, as it decreases diversity.

 Quinn presents an interesting analogy in some of his works that compares our global culture to the inventor of a 'flying machine' that throws a bunch of odds and ends together and drops his invention off of a very high cliff. Much more efficient and practical than controlling pollution released directly from vehicles.
 
 One thing that has not come yet with regard to EROEI is fusion power. Surely this presents something akin to the holy grail of EROEI. The technology is not at a practical stage yet- it takes more energy to start the reaction than that which is released, but when a sustainable reaction is achieved the potential seems amazing. There is some radioactive waste to consider with this method (namely the reactor chambers) but it is less persistent than that produced by fission reactors (ie. a half life of tens of years as opposed to thousands).
 
 Currently JET (Joint European Torus) is at the cutting edge of fusion research, but is a way off from commercial application. The next step is the ITER which aims to produce a net gain in energy (by a factor of 10-20 times) and act as a platform from which commercial fusion power can be evolved.
 
 It might take 40 years before commerical fusion power is reality, but that reality would be a remarkable one indeed.

But with oil breaking the US$50-a-barrel barrier in October, and amid other concerns, the peak oil crowd is grabbing more attention. One of their most startling claims is the following: six barrels of oil are now used for every new barrel discovered. Major oil finds - that is, more than 500 million barrels - peaked in 1964. In 2000, there were 13 such discoveries; in 2001, six; in 2002, two; and in 2003, zero - the first time that had ever happened. 
 
 The "peak" oil analysts also say oil-industry investment patterns seem to indicate that there isn't much oil left to discover

 
 The above gives a very strong indication that the World is basically living on past oil discoveries, even if we havent reached "peak oil" we are no longer finding the cheap oil that we did in the past. 
 
 
But if discoveries are down and supplies dipping, demand is up. Driving it is population growth led by China, with 1.3 billion people. Buoyed by an economic boom, China has overtaken Japan as the world's second oil-consuming country after the United States. 
 
 The US Department of Energy predicts that through 2020, energy consumption in China will rise about 4.3% a year, and by at least 3% in three other large developing countries: India, Brazil and Mexico. 
 
 Aleklett and other peak oil analysts warn that meeting future demand without seriously drawing down reserves is impossible. Aleklett said China is aware that oil will be scarcer in the future and is scrambling to buy up or contract for as much oil as it can - even negotiating with Canada, America's top energy supplier.  
 Possible Sino-American jousting for Canadian oil could be just a glimpse of what will be a more fierce global competition for black gold. Michael T Klare, author of Resources Wars, noted that the biggest oil supplies are found in some of the most volatile regions: the Middle East, the Caucasus and Central Asia. He said major world powers won't be drawn into direct conflict there but they won't sit on the sidelines, either.
